content: The Act may be cited as the "Violent Crime Control Act of 1993". The Congress finds that there is a lack of reliable information on ammunition availability, importers and manufacturers are not required to report to the Federal Government, a loophole allows unlimited gun orders, bullet-related deaths are increasing, certain calibers are used disproportionately in crime, and young males, especially young black males, are most affected by injury and death from bullets. Epidemiology can be used to study bullet-related deaths. The lack of reliable information on ammunition availability and the loophole allowing unlimited gun orders have contributed to the increase in bullet-related deaths and injuries. A tax on bullet sales is proposed to help control this issue, as there is no central agency responsible for trauma and limited funding available for studying bullet-related deaths. Increased research in bullet-related violence is necessary to understand the causes, develop control options, and overcome barriers to effective measures. Current laws and programs are inadequate to protect citizens from bullet-related trauma. The purpose of increased research in bullet-related violence is to understand causes, develop control options, and overcome barriers to effective measures. The Act aims to increase taxes on certain bullets to reduce bullet-related deaths and injuries. It also seeks to gather data on bullet-related incidents, assess trends over time, and educate the public on the issue. The Act aims to reduce bullet-related deaths and injuries by increasing taxes on certain bullets, gathering data on incidents, assessing trends, educating the public, developing options for control, building capacity, promoting understanding of the epidemiologic approach, and controlling the proliferation of illegal firearms. The Act establishes a Bullet Death and Injury Control Program to reduce bullet-related deaths and injuries through various measures such as increasing taxes on certain bullets, gathering data on incidents, educating the public, and controlling the proliferation of illegal firearms. Established within the Centers for Disease Control's National Center for Injury Prevention and Control is a Bullet Death and Injury Control Program. The Program aims to conduct research, provide leadership, and coordinate efforts to understand, prevent, and educate the public about bullet-related deaths and injuries in the United States. The Bullet Death and Injury Control Program, established within the CDC, aims to enhance knowledge, conduct research, and publish information on bullet-related deaths and injuries in the US. The Bullet Death and Injury Control Program, established within the CDC, aims to provide practical guides for epidemiological research on bullet-related deaths and injuries, identify areas in need of study, conduct research through various means, and make recommendations to Congress. The Bullet Death and Injury Control Program within the CDC aims to provide recommendations to Congress, ATF, and other agencies on data management for analyzing and controlling bullet-related deaths and injuries. It also offers guidance on actions to reduce this epidemic and provides training to relevant agencies. The Bullet Death and Injury Control Program at the CDC aims to provide recommendations to Congress, ATF, and other agencies on data management for analyzing and controlling bullet-related deaths and injuries. It also offers guidance on actions to reduce this epidemic and provides training to relevant agencies. The Center has an independent advisory board consisting of 13 members from various agencies and organizations. The advisory board for the Bullet Death and Injury Control Program at the CDC consists of 13 members from different agencies and organizations, including criminologists, behavioral scientists, physicians, statisticians, engineers, and public communications experts from universities or nonprofit organizations. Members serve 5-year terms and may serve multiple terms. Compensation is provided to members who are not federal government officers or employees. Members of the advisory board for the Bullet Death and Injury Control Program at the CDC, who are not federal government officers or employees, will be compensated at a rate equivalent to level IV of the Executive Schedule. Officers or employees of the United States serving on the Commission will not receive additional compensation. Non-government members may also receive travel expenses and per diem as provided in appropriations Acts. The advisory board members for the Bullet Death and Injury Control Program will be compensated at a rate equivalent to level IV of the Executive Schedule. The Center will consult with the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, and Firearms and the Department of Justice. $1,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 1993, increasing to $5,000,000 for fiscal years 1995-1997. The Center will provide an annual report to Congress on the Program's progress and findings. The report for December 31, 1995, will include options and recommendations for the Program's mission and funding levels for the years 1996-2000 and beyond. SEC. 201. INCREASE IN TAX ON CERTAIN BULLETS. SEC. 201. INCREASE IN TAX ON CERTAIN BULLETS. Amends the Internal Revenue Code to increase the tax rate on 9mm, .25 caliber, or .32 caliber ammunition to 1,000 percent. Exempts sales to law enforcement entities and sets the effective date for sales after December 31, 1995. SEC. 301. RECORDS OF DISPOSITION OF AMMUNITION. Amendment of Title 18, United States Code, requires licensed importers and manufacturers of ammunition to maintain records of importation, production, shipment, sale, or other disposition of ammunition at their place of business as prescribed by the Secretary in consultation with the Centers for Disease Control. The records must include the amount, caliber, and type of ammunition. Licensed importers and manufacturers of ammunition must annually prepare a summary report of imports, production, shipments, sales, and other dispositions. The report, to be submitted to the specified office, should include details on amounts, calibers, and types of ammunition. The Secretary of the Treasury is tasked with requesting the Centers for Disease Control to study criminal use and regulation of ammunition. The Secretary of the Treasury will ask the Centers for Disease Control to conduct a study on the criminal use and regulation of ammunition. A report with recommendations on preventing crime by regulating ammunition availability must be submitted to Congress by July 31, 1996. SEC. 401. Compliance with state and local firearms licensing laws required for federal license issuance. Section 923(d)(1) of title 18, United States Code is amended to include requirements for applicants seeking a license to deal in firearms, such as compliance with state and local laws and a written statement signed by law enforcement officials. The amendment to Section 923(d)(1) of title 18, United States Code requires applicants for a firearms license to comply with state and local laws and obtain a written statement from law enforcement officials certifying their eligibility. This amendment applies to license applications issued on or after the enactment of this Act.
